children.value: In this notebook, you will ingest Landsat data for use in machine learning. Machine learning tasks often involve a lot of data, and in Python, data is typically stored in memory as simple
arrays. However, higher-level containers built on top of NumPy arrays provide more functionality for multidimensional gridded data (
). Our goal for data ingestion will be to load specific Landsat data of interest into one of these higher-level containers.
is one of several providers of
. We are using it together with
because together they provide a nice Python API for searching and loading with specific criteria such as spatial area, datetime, Landsat mission, and cloud coverage.

Earth science datasets are often stored on remote servers that may be too large to download locally. Therefore, in this cookbook, we will focus primarily on ingestion approaches that load small portions of data from a remote source, as needed. However, the approach for your own work will depend not only on data size and location but also the intended analysis, so in a follow up notebook, you will see an alternative approache for generalized data access and management.

import odc.stac
import pandas as pd
import planetary_computer
import pystac_client
import xarray as xr
from pystac.extensions.eo import EOExtension as eo

# Viz
import hvplot.xarray
import panel as pn

pn.extension()

children.value: Open and read the root of the STAC catalog

children.label: Open and read the root of the STAC catalog

children.value: Microsoft Planetary Computer has a public STAC metadata but the actual data assets are in private Azure Blob Storage containers and require authentication.
keyword that we can use to manually sign the item. Otherwise, we’d get an error when trying to access the asset.
Let’s say that an analysis we want to run requires landsat data over a specific region and from a specific time period. We can use our catalog to search for assets that fit our search criteria.
First, let’s find the name of the landsat dataset.
is a nice resource for browsing the available collections, but we can also just search the catalog for ‘landsat’:

all_collections = [i.id for i in catalog.get_collections()]
landsat_collections = [
    collection for collection in all_collections if "landsat" in collection
]
landsat_collections
dataset, which stands for Collection 2 Level-2. It contains data from several landsat missions and has better data quality than Level 1 (
). Microsoft Planetary Computer has descriptions of
, but a direct and succinct comparison can be found in
, and the information can be verified with
Now, let’s set our search parameters. You may already know the bounding box (region/area of interest) coordinates, but if you don’t, there are many useful tools like

bbox = [-118.89, 38.54, -118.57, 38.84]  # Region over a lake in Nevada, USA
datetime = "2017-06-01/2017-09-30"  # Summer months of 2017
collection = "landsat-c2-l2"
We can also specify other parameters in the query, such as a specific landsat mission and the max percent of cloud cover:
Now we run the search and list the results:

search = catalog.search(
    collections=["landsat-c2-l2"],
    bbox=bbox,
    datetime=datetime,
    query={"eo:cloud_cover": {"lt": cloudy_less_than}, "platform": {"in": [platform]}},
)
items = search.item_collection()
print(f"Returned {len(items)} Items:")
item_id = {(i, item.id): i for i, item in enumerate(items)}
item_id

data.evalue: The request exceeded the maximum allowed time, please try again. If the issue persists, please contact planetarycomputer@microsoft.com.

children.value: It looks like there were three image stacks taken by Landsat 8 over this spatial region during the summer months of 2017 that has less than 1 percent cloud cover.
Preview Results and Select a Dataset

children.label: Preview Results and Select a Dataset

children.value: Before loading one of the available image stacks, it would be useful to get a visual check of the results. Many datasets have a rendered preview or thumbnail image that can be accessed without having to load the full resolution data.
We can create a simple interactive application using the

library to access and display rendered PNG previews of the our search results. Note that these pre-rendered images are of large tiles that span beyond our bounding box of interest. In the next steps, we will only be loading in a small area around the lake.

Now that we have selected a dataset from our catalog, we can procede to access the data. We want to be very selective about the data that we read and when we read it because the amount of downloaded data can quickly get out of hand. Therefore, let’s select only a subset of images.
First, we’ll preview the different image assets (or

assets = []
for _, asset in selected_item.assets.items():
    try:
        assets.append(asset.extra_fields["eo:bands"][0])
    except:
        pass

cols_ordered = [
    "common_name",
    "description",
    "name",
    "center_wavelength",
    "full_width_half_max",
]
bands = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(assets)[cols_ordered]
bands
Then we will select a few bands (images) of interest:
Finally, we lazily load the selected data. We will use the package called
which allows us to load only a specific region of interest (bounding box or ‘bbox’) and specific bands (images) of interest. We will also use the
argument to load the data as dask arrays; this will load the metadata now and delay the loading until we actually use the data, or until we force the data to be loaded by using

ds = odc.stac.stac_load(
    [selected_item],
    bands=bands_of_interest,
    bbox=bbox,
    chunks={},  # <-- use Dask
).isel(time=0)
ds
Let’s combine the bands of the dataset into a single DataArray that has the band names as coordinates of a new ‘band’ dimension, and also call

Often, data ingestion involves quickly visualizing your raw data to get a sense that things are proceeding accordingly. As we have created an array with red, blue, and green bands, we can quickly display a natural color image of the lake using the
argument because the data values are outside the range of typical RGB images.
to provide an interactive visualization of the inividual bands in our array.
Let’s plot the bands as seperate columns by specifying a dimension to expand with

(another HoloViz tool) to render large data into a 2D histogram, where every array cell counts the data points falling into that pixel, as set by the resolution of your screen. This is especially important for large and high resolution images that would otherwise cause issues when attempting to render in a browser.
Select the zoom tool and zoom in on of the plots to see that all the images are all automatically linked!
When working with many image arrays, it’s critical to retain the data properties as xarray attributes:
Notice that you can now expand the
dropdown to see the properties of this data.
As the data is in ‘meter’ units from a reference point, we can plot in commonly used longitude, latitude coordinates with
if our array has a valid coordinate reference system (CRS) attribute. This value is provided from Microsoft Planetary Computer as the
property, so we just need to copy it to a new attribute
so that hvPlot can automatically find it, without us having to further specify anything in our plotting code
Note, this CRS is referenced by an EPSG code that can be accessed from the metadata of our selected catalog search result. We can see more about this dataset’s specific code at
. You can also read more about EPSG codes in general in this
to plot in longitude and latitude coordinates. Informing
that this is geographic data also allows us to overlay data on aligned geographic tiles using the
The data access approach should adapt to features of the data and your intended analysis. As Landsat data is large and multidimensional, a good approach is to use
together for searching the metadata catalog and lazily loading specific data chunks. Once you have accessed data, visualize it with hvPlot to ensure that it matches your expectations.
Before we proceed to workflow examples, we can explore an alternate way of accessing data using generalized tooling.
